Pantocrat saw the building first.

It hadn't gotten any worse, but I'd had enough of walking and definitely didn't want to spend another night under the stars.

Pantocrat, Zoby and I (Coctail) had been walking on this dusty land dotted with undergrowth for days. We had filled all possible containers before we left, but the warm water was running out even quicker than we had hoped. At times my mind wandered and I saw myself bathing in a frozen lake, far away from the zombies who were following us.

They were slow, untiring, and smelt dreadful. They walked much slower than us, but it was as though they were drawn to us. During the day, we managed to lose them, but at night... at night, we would hear them coming and we'd have to decamp and get going in a hurry.

++

Every now and then, we would see the silhouettes of more depressing puppets approaching us. We would pick up the pace, and eventually they would join the horde that was following us, swelling their ranks a little each day.

As we got closer, we could see the building better. The lower level was broad, and the first floor smaller with an antenna on the roof. I soon saw the bodies lying next to the building.

I looked at Zoby, my companion. He looked even more miserable than the day we met. His lips were encrusted with blood. Out of the three of us, he was the worst at dealing with the relentless sunshine but he was the best handyman, which is a crucial skill if you want to survive in this world. It was Zoby who built my 'Zombiegrater'. I wouldn't give up that sharpened shard of metal for anything.

++

The air was becoming hazy from the heat. Each step was a struggle but the shelter was slowly getting closer... slowly...

That's whan Pantocrat yelled out.

He had just seen 5 zombies who were coming towards us, blocking us from reaching the building.

I didn't want to walk any more. I was thirsty. I'd had enough of being hunted like an animal. I didn't study and work hard to end up being tracked by a horde of the living dead...

++

I've had enough.

This building is what I'd had my sights set on for days now. All I wanted was to at least be able to close my eyes which were dry and puffy from lack of sleep. ++

I've had enough.

The sun was beating down on my head as the five wretched corpses approached. Pantocrat and Zoby were discussing how we could bypass them. Zoby anxiously watched the setting sun and was worried that we couldn't make a big enough detour to completely escape them.

++

I've had enough.

I wanted to scream, but no sound came out of my throat as I ran towards them, Zombiegrater at the ready.

I opened my aching eyes.

Pantocrat passed me a damp cloth for my forehead. I was in the shadows. I closed my eyes again to make the most of the coolness.

I would never previously have appreciated the simple act of lying in the twilight shad...

The sun! My contentment was shortlived...

The sun had gone down!

++

They were coming ! We had to hide !

- “He's awake”, Pantocrat yelled behind him.

- “Just as well, he can help me to push this fridge in front of the window ! “, Zoby responded softly.

We finally managed to barricade the basement with what little solid furniture we could find.

We didn't stop until the night was over. Pantocrat and Zoby told me that they saw me running towards the zombies and killing them one by one. After which I vanished. They found me and dragged me here.

++

They even managed to find some water. It was probably left over from someone taking a bath. Fortunately they had the presence of mind to get out before they died. We found their skeleton next to the wash hand basin. Obviously, no water came out of the taps and there was even less electricity.

Given my weakened state, my friends left me to sleep on the remains of the couch. Pantocrat stood guard that night, with his blunderbuss in his hand.

I didn't wake up until Zoby shook me. The sun was already high in the sky. Zoby kicked Pantocrat's sleeping silhouette which was faithfully standing guard.

We were so tired that we didn't hear any noises during the night, but judging by the impact marks and scratches on the walls, the zombies must have been pretty relentless...

++

Cautiously, we went outside. It seemed as though the horde had momentarily retreated.

Having spent the evening barricading ourselves inside the building, we didn't have the chance to search the nearby vehicles.

They were all really rusty and generally in a sorry state. Everything seems to have deteriorated so quickly of late, everything...

We were trying the vehicles without success when I heard an engine starting. What an engine it was too ! He had managed to start up a half-track ! One of those all-terrain army vehicles that is driven by caterpillar tracks at the back. He killed the engine and climbed down.

His smile reminded me of the Cheshire cat from Alice in Wonderland. At least it did, until white smoke started billowing from under the hood.

++

Pantocrat reappeared, running towards us. He had just found a ruined building which was covered in earth.

We divided the tasks amongst ourselves. I was to get digging with my Zombiegrater, while Pantocrat reclaimed sheet metal from the vehicles to reinforce our barricades. Zoby, on finding a toolbox, set to seeing what he could salvage from the half-track.

We worked hard that day, but fortunately Pantocrat brought me a shovel after a few hours. I almost cried with gratitude as my hands were so badly scratched.

That evening, we barricaded ourslves into the building which now ressembled a heap of scrap metal. Pantocrat collected all the car hoods and fixed them to the ground-floor windows. He also pushed a van in front of one of the doors to stop the zombies getting through.

++

Zoby managed to get the half-track motor going again, and siphoned the fuel out of the other tanks. He even found jerry cans and filled them.

We went up to the first floor to decide if we should leave immediately of if we should reinforce the half-track. Heads turned towards me, but I said nothing.

I shot them a huge smile and went outside, with a greasy cloth concealing a bottle of booze which I'd found while digging.

Each of us was only allowed ten drinks, due to the rarity of such a find...

I decided to take go first.

After a few minutes, Pantocrat and Zoby were snoring in unison.

++

With nothing better to do, I went upstairs to watch the moon through one of the broken windows. Zombies aren't agile enough to climb walls, so there was no point in barricading other levels.

I was absent-mindedly watching the breeze blowing the aerial on the van when I heard them

The were letting out gutteral moans as they crossed the desert.

The horde was coming

And with it, that smell of flesh warmed by the sun. ...

I heard them beating on the hoods which we had riveted to the walls. Good thinking by Pantocrat. The hoods gave us good protection. Good protection, but pretty bloody noisy. I was kept awake all night with the infernal din.

++

I kept it together and saw the night through. Fortunately, because just before the sun came up I saw a head appear in front of the first-floor window.

A head without a jaw. I yelled to warn the others and got my grater out.

Its head flew outside, but the rest of it kept coming towards me, waving its claws in the air.

I managed to overcome the headless horde member just as my two companions arrived behind me.

Zoby let out a yell and pointed at the window.

Absorbed in the fight, I hadn't noticed that four other zombies had returned and even more were on their way.

++

We threw ourselves as one towards the door and while Pantocrat and Zoby braced themselves against it to keep it shut, I ran around in all senses of the word to find something to jam it shut. I finally found the couch, and using the energy of desperation alone, I managed to drag it upstairs.

It was just in time because the door had started to crack and splinter. Zoby helped me to wedge it between the door and the wall opposite. The couch was now jammed and blocked the entire passage, but at least the zombies couldn't get past it.

Their assault went on until midday.

We cautiously made our way outside, and Zoby and I shot Pantocrat a dirty look when we discovered that the only reason the zombies made it upstairs was thanks to his strategically placed van...

++

Pantocrat climbed up onto the van and got back down just as quickly. He was completely pale. It wasn't easy to see under the sunburn and peeling skin, but despite his stammering we could understand that there were still a dozen zombies in the room behind our barricades. The same zombies who climbed to our hideout the night before, but didn't leave with the rest of the horde and instead stayed in our shelter.

Without saying a word, I went to find the bottle of alcohol, and took a huge gulp for courage, took a lighter from Pantocrat's pocket and climbed onto the van.

++

The screams of burning zombies went on for several hours.

By the next night, Pantocrat had transformed the building into a fortress and had pushed the offending van away. Zoby had built a steel-plated cabin on the back of the half-track and I had finally unearthed the building. Tonight I plan to open the several crates I managed to get out on casters i'd found during the night.

That night, the only noises came from Zoby. I was curled up in a ball, completely shattered while Zoby persevered with trying to pop padlocks with his screwdriver.

In the middle of the night, Pantocrat woke me up. He ended up sawing the bottoms off the crates. I saw that he had a bloody bandage wrapped round his hand and three broken screwdrivers at his feet...

I was about to go on a rant about wasting precious tools, when he told me what the crates contained.

++

I picked up the heavy machine gun and checked its balance. I knew it had come from a military weapons cache.

I put the weapon down on the ground and embraced my friends.

I was practically jumping for joy until Zoby killed the mood :

“I guess all we need now is bullets...”

There was no attack that night.

++

The next day was devoted to frantically unearthing the weapons cache.

As was the day after.

The next day was spent repairing the breach in the wall from the previous night's attack.

The following night was the most frightful since we arrived. We had to shut ourselves in the bathroom.

The zombies screamed and groaned. I broke my grater containing them in the corridor while Pantocrat and Zoby gathered what we needed to barricade ourselves in.

The last sheet of metal was going to give way imminently under their increasing weight.

++

Pantocrat took a look around and the only thing left that wasn't blocking the door was the bath. Our only water reserve.

Zoby and I yelled and cried, but Pantocrat had already turned it over, saying : “no need to hesitate now – if it's empty, it can ONLY be used as a barricade.” In any case, we either die now like trapped rats or we die of thirst later. Best to die later.

We managed to resist throwing Pantocrat out the window to occupy the zombies for a while.

Even more so, as the zombies gave up pretty much as soon as we put the bath against the door.

++

We still hadn't found any ammunition and we had no water left.

Thankfully Zoby had finished with the half-track. So we loaded some (empty) weapons, the tools we had found, and all the screws we could gather as it was becoming evident that the building wouldn't withstand a determined assault by an increasingly larger horde.

We had decided to scavenge until the zombies came. Pantocrat was nominated to climb on top of the building to act as lookout.

Pantocrat yelled out, so Zoby and I hurriedly dealt with a case of explosives we'd just found.

Pantocrat drove, with Zoby sat next to him. He fired up the cassette player and classic rock blared. Combined with the interference, it covered up the engine noise nicely.

++

Sat in the back, I watched the horde shuffling behind us, their empty eyes fixed on the grey dust cloud which the half-track was kicking up.

The sun set, cutting sinister silhouettes into the landscape.

Behind us, a dirty piece of fabric attached to the roof antenna started to fly in the wind, revealing a particularly bad drawing of a unicorn...

La ville attire de plus en plus de zombies.

Sortons tous de la ville : si les zombies veulent entrer, qu'ils entrent, nous, on aura le désert.

On finira bien par trouver assez de ressources pour construire une nouvelle ville.

++

J'ai trouvé un moteur et un cochon.

Avec le moteur et un peu de ferraille, une caisse à outils et un peu d'alcool, je peux fabriquer un camion.

Alimenté par l'alcool, l'engin pourrait nous transporter tous loin de tous ces cadavres mouvants.

(le cochon ne sert à rien)

++

Les zombies s'ammassent chaque nuit devant nos maisons.

Ils doivent rechercher quelqu'un en particulier; c'est pas possible sinon. Tirons à la courte paille et jettons quelqu'un dehors chaque nuit pour savoir si c'est lui qu'ils cherchent.

Après un moment, nous aurons bien trouvé de qui il s'agit et les autres seront tranquilles.

++ ||

Je vais lire un conte d'horreur aux zombies, il n'oseront plus jamais revenir.

++

Dans le désert, les zombies font les malins. dans la ville, c'est nous.

Baissons le prix des terrains, construisons des stades de foot, implantons un Mac Donald's, faisons venir des célébrités, construisons des HLM.

Nous aurons une métropole et les zombies serons relégués dans des réserves.

Mettons-nous à chanter pour faire pleuvoir. Nous serons tranquilles.

Quelqu'un a-t-il déjà essayé de leur parler ? Quelqu'un a-t-il déjà essayé de savoir ce qu'ils veulent ?

Ils veulent peut-être juste l’égalité des votes et, tout en manifestant, prennent la ville pour un groupe de CRS...

Depuis des années, les vivants ont mis les morts dans les tombes. Les morts en ont marre et en sont sortis.

Pourquoi ne pas l’accepter et nous cacher dans leurs tombes ? Ils ne penseront JAMAIS à nous chercher là-bas !

Les zombies nous admirent. La journée, nous sortons faire des expéditions et la nuit, nous rentrons dans la ville.

Un petit journal très ancien, vous avez peur qu’il tombe en lambeaux si vous essayez de l’ouvrir. Le nom de l’auteur est effacé... Peut-être un témoignage des temps anciens ?

Mercredi 26 septembre 1963

Aujourd’hui nous sommes sortis pique-niquer avec Sam et les enfants. Cela fait du bien de sortir un peu du labo. Toutes ces blouses blanches, à longueur de temps, cela fatigue... Voir un peu de verdure ne peut que me faire du bien et je pense avoir besoin de tout moyen de décompresser avant l’expérience de la semaine prochaine. Ce sera l’aboutissement de nos recherches, un moyen que le monde nous croit finalement... Nous leur offrons l’immortalité...

++

Vendredi 28 septembre 1963

Hier, John a protesté contre l’expérience, clamant nos méthodes « inhumaines ». Il hurlait « et si cela ne marchait pas ? Et si quelque chose tournait mal ? ». Nous ne pouvons nous permettre de douter... Aujourd’hui, John a l’air en retrait, il est bien loin de son enthousiasme révolutionnaire d’hier...

Samedi 29 septembre 1963

John n’était pas présent aujourd’hui... C’est étrange, en 5 ans de bons et loyaux services, il n’a pas raté une seule journée de travail. Et si ? Non, pas de doute permis. Je m’étais dis que je passerai chez lui après le travail mais je n’en ai pas eu le temps. Demain, je l’espère !

++

Dimanche 30 septembre 1963

Exceptionnellement on nous a convoqués au labo aujourd’hui... C’est compréhensible, nous devons nous assurer que tout est prêt pour l’expérience ! Nous allons enfin passer à des sujets vivants, c’est un grand moment et la pression est palpable parmi nous... Si tout fonctionne, nous serons considérés comme des dieux... Mais si quelque chose venait à tourner mal... Non, tout ira bien. Le pessimisme n’est pas de rigueur.

Après le travail, je suis allé chez John. Arrivé à sa porte, j’ai entendu des espèces de sombres grognements. J’ai frappé, une fois, deux fois, trois fois, pas de réponse. La porte était ouverte, je suis donc entré vérifier que tout allait bien.

++

Sa femme était assise à la table du salon, me tournant le dos. A l’aide... Je m’en approchais, l’interpellant, sans réponse.

Alors que je posais ma main sur son épaule, sa tête se retourna soudainement avant de se détacher de son corps et de tomber à terre...

D’effroi, je bondis en arrière et trébuchai sur le tapis. Arrivé au niveau du sol, je vis ses deux enfants, le corps lacéré par terre, la chair de leur visage arrachée et un vaste trou dans le crâne. Je me relevai ..ma tête... et pris la direction de la porte en courant quand j’aperçus John.

Ou plutôt le souvenir de John.

++

Il avait les yeux vitreux, la peau grisâtre, les traits tirés et était recouvert de sang. Il s’approchait de moi lentement. J’ai si faim... J’étais paralysé. Arrivé à distance, il m’empoigna et sa bouche se précipita vers mon épaule qu’il mordit avec force. J’ai si froid... Dans un cri de douleur, j’attrapais un chandelier qui traînait sur la table et le frappait avec force à la tête. J’ai si mal... Il s’affala alors que je sortais en trombe de chez lui, me dirigeant chez moi pour me soigner.

Dans la soirée, mes blessures - pas si profondes que cela - pansées J’ai si faim... Je, faim,... Sam approche.. me touche le cou. J’ai faim... Tout est bientôt fini...

Le reste du journal est maculé de sang.

Jour 2. J'enfile ma tenue de camouflage. Je dois faire un repérage du parcours pour l'expédition prévue plus tard dans la journée.

Etude analytique de l'anatomie et du comportement des non-vivants

Chapitre 1 : étude morphologique comparative

++

L'ensemble de cette étude vise à décrire ceux que nous appelleront les non-vivants. Dans ce premier chapitre, nous allons comparer un homme moyen en bonne santé, et un non-vivant. Sur le plan de l'allure générale, ils sont de même constitution. Après un examen plus poussé, force est de constater que le non-vivant présente un état de décomposition plus ou moins avancée, ce qui est à l'origine des différences physiques (membres et/ou organes manquants). Le déplacement d'un humain normal est de type bipède, celui d'un non-vivant varie en fonction de son état (de bipède jusqu'à gastéropode). A souligner : même en l'absence de bras ou de jambes, un non-vivant continuera de tenter d'avancer vers son repas.

++

Enfin, sur le plan de la force physique, la force d'un humain moyen est équivalente à celle de deux non-vivants.

||

Etude analytique de l'anatomie et du comportement des non-vivants

Chapitre 2 : moeurs diurnes et nocturnes

++

Les non-vivants sont relativement amorphes le jour. Cela peut s'expliquer vraisemblablement par la faible résistance de leur organisme au soleil, notre astre accélérant leur flétrissement.

En revanche, la nuit ils font preuve d'une grande activité, et n'hésitent pas à assaillir les villes qui se trouvent sur leur territoire afin de nourrir leur insatiable appétit. Pendant près d'une demi-heure, ils sont capables de déployer des trésors de ruses et de force afin de pénétrer les plus solides barricades.

Etude analytique de l'anatomie et du comportement des non-vivants

Chapitre 3 : reproduction de l'espèce

++

De part leur nature, les non-vivants sont une espèce totalement nouvelle.

Ils ne sont ni ovipares, ni vivipares, et même en l'absence d'outils pour l'affirmer, je pense qu'ils ne se reproduisent pas non plus de façon communément admise (un mâle, une femelle).

De fait, il est maintenant quasiment sûr qu'ils se reproduisent par contact buccal. Si un humain normalement constitué est mordu (et/ou dévoré de façon atroce) par l'un d'entre eux, à courte échéance, il deviendra également un non-vivant. S'il meurt durant le processus d'alimentation, il se relèvera dans les minutes qui suivent. Par contre, si l'individu mordu survit, le processus prendra plusieurs heures au minimum.

++

Il est très intéressant de noter que l'alimentation et la reproduction sont intimement liées, nous rappelant ainsi les anciennes orgies antiques.

Enfin, que le non-vivant et le mordu soit mâles ou femelles n'influence en rien le processus.

Sliding off the stool, his shoes hit the dirt wood floor and the boy ran past the other workers, through the dusty paths, the man stared after him with concern, “I’ll check on em soon as I’m done here.”

The boy stopped short of the green tent, glancing side to side with suspicious eyes, nobody, nothing, zilch, not even the wind blew. “Mommie.” He whispered, opening the flap, it was dark inside, but he saw the outline of his mother huddled near the back, “Are you feeling better?” She moved back and forth in a whole body nod. He slid in, the flap let a sliver of sun in, his saw his mother’s hand was red and puffy. Walking on his knees, he saw the open canteen, “Oh good,” picking it up, “you drank…”

++

A low growl made the plastic tent shake, “Mommie?” He clutched the canteen, eyes wide with fear; slowly he stepped back on his knees.

Her moans became louder, higher, rougher, he swallowed and she turned around, the streak of sun cutting across her body. Her dirty hair clumped up in bunches, yellow patches bulged around her face, her eyes were bloodshot, she gritted her thin yellow teeth, her son’s mouth opened, she growled like a dog swollen hands swiping for him. He knew the zombies melted at the contact of water, he held the open canteen, unsure, he looked to his mother; the yellow bulges broke open, puss and blood gushed out, he felt a surge of acid tickle his throat. She lunged at him; knocking straight into the canteen, water dumped into the new open wounds, she couldn’t scream, her throat was melting away...

...Chunks of flesh dripped onto the sandy plastic, her fingers were mostly bone from clutching her water downed throat, her eyes open in terror, head tilted, the boy just stared at his mother covered in water, blood and sand, the smell of rotten meat tickling his stomach to puke. He finally did.

Wiping his mouth, he began to cry. “It’s ok mommie.” He crawled to her and curled up on the reeking corpse. Wrapping his fingers around her squishy, still warm hands, he shut his eyes and hummed a soft lullaby.

“Here to check on yah.” the man said outside the tent, holding the flashlight down. He heard nothing and opened the tent flap slowly, “Are you ok?” The flashlight circled on the boy sleeping on what was left of his mother.

++

Her body was more of a puddle seeping into her uniform, her hands were barely intact now between the boy’s, his clothes also sopping wet. A wave of rotten smell burned his nose; he covered his face and kept starting, trying not to gag.



The boy’s eyelids moved, clicking the flashlight off he plunged into the tent feeling the ooze between his hands, lifting the boy up from the stick with a sick sound of popping bones.

++


The thick air choked the man’s throat, the crinkling plastic was slippery on his large knees, his shoes were wet from the melting remains, “You’re ok, you’re ok, you’re ok.” He whispered for himself and the boy when he shouldered through the flap, opening his lungs to the dry clear air, the boy still clutched his mother’s hands under the dim desert stars, a breeze whispered; taking the smell of death far away to somewhere and the man wept.
